title: Are we responsible for our actions? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve heard that all of the decisions we make consciously have already been made emotionally and whatever reason we give for making them is just justification after the fact. Free will is a tricky subject. There is so much that takes place in our subconscious and so much that is the product of conditioning. When we are forced to make an instantaneous decision, do we get a chance to think about it or did we have to do something right now without that luxury? Are we responsible for that decision, or was it made under some kind of duress? What if the only choice we are given is “Hobson’s Choice”, in which there really only is one option in spite of the illusion of there being more than one? If you don’t really get a choice, are you responsible for choosing the only option available to you? Many people are never taught how to make decisions at all, because they are never offered options in childhood. The first time they endeavor to make a decision they have to do it by trial and error. People make mistakes. And many people find themselves in one of those positions. They don’t know everything they would need to know to make an informed decision. They literally don’t know any better. Sometimes they don’t really have as many choices as they would appear to have. Life is complicated and other situations might impose their own limitations on what choices we have, especially if they involve other people. There are often mitigating circumstances, hence the saying “circumstances alter cases”. I’m not saying that this absolves people of bad choices made freely and with all of the information. If it can be shown that we did know what we were doing and it was possible for us to choose differently, then yes, people are responsible for their actions. Unfortunately it isn’t always so clear-cut. So are people fully responsible for their actions? Sometimes, but not always. Hobson's choice - Wikipedia What Does Circumstances Alter Cases Mean? - Writing Explained

Reaping flowers by author There are cases where every person was corporately responsible for the actions of one person. In this example case no one was to take spoils of victory over an wicked city marked for destruction for their corporate evil. But one person didn’t have the moral courage not to take and hide gold and riches. As a result a lot of people were killed by a few enemies. Joshua said, "Alas, O Lord GOD, why did You ever bring this people over the Jordan, only to deliver us into the hand of the Amorites, to destroy us? If only we had been willing to dwell beyond the Jordan! O Lord, what can I say since Israel has turned their back before their enemies? For the Canaanites and all the inhabitants of the land will hear of it, and they will surround us and cut off our name from the earth. And what will You do for Your great name?" So the LORD said to Joshua, "Rise up! Why is it that you have fallen on your face? Israel has sinned, and they have also transgressed My covenant which I commanded them. And they have even taken some of the things under the ban and have both stolen and deceived. Moreover, they have also put them among their own things. (Joshua 7:7–11 NASB*) They found the traitor with the goods hidden under his tent then stoned his entire family. Pretty rough “taking responsibility.“ But it stopped their loses in battle. But that was a special case for a people in a special covenant with the creator of man. Now that creator God determines who is responsible for their actions when it’s sin: The person who sins will die. The son will not bear the punishment for the father's iniquity, nor will the father bear the punishment for the son's iniquity; the righteousness of the righteous will be upon himself, and the wickedness of the wicked will be upon himself. (Ezekiel 18:20, NASB*) It is clear that you are responsible for your own actions. It is a reap what you sow concept. In this passage in the Holy Bible the term “sow” is the image of someone who throws out grain to grow wheat in a field. It is a metaphor for sowing actions the result in effects that show up afterwards. Do not be deceived, God is not mocked; for whatever a man sows, this he will also reap. For the one who sows to his own flesh will from the flesh reap corruption, but the one who sows to the Spirit will from the Spirit reap eternal life. (Galatians 6:7,8 NASB*) Two types of things are “sowed” in these Bible verses. One thing to the flesh and the other to the Spirit. Earlier in the Bible these things were defined from partial lists so you would get the idea. Now the deeds of the flesh are evident, which are: immorality, impurity, sensuality, idolatry, sorcery, enmities, strife, jealousy, outbursts of anger, disputes, dissensions, factions, envying, drunkenness, carousing, and things like these, of which I forewarn you, just as I have forewarned you, that those who practice such things will not inherit the kingdom of God. But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, self-control; against such things there is no law. (Galatians 5:19–23 NASB*) When each person is judged by the creator God, He will look at your actions and you ways of behaving. I, the LORD, have spoken; it is coming and I will act. I will not relent, and I will not pity and I will not be sorry; according to your ways and according to your deeds I will judge you," declares the Lord GOD.'" (Ezekiel 24:14, NASB*) God is absolutely fair and impartial in this judgement there isn’ t a bribe or a favorite people or excuse that will sway Him. If you address as Father the One who impartially judges according to each one's work, conduct yourselves in fear during the time of your stay on earth; (1 Peter 1:17, NASB*) If God was inconsistent and turned an eye away from what someone did or didn’t do then He would not be God. But the God of the Bible is not partial. So you are responsible for your actions before God and this for your own sins in any deeds of the flesh. And since every person is a sinner they have to die for their own sins. I can not die for the penalty of your sins nor in the reverse of you dying for mine. Christianity is based on the fact that God took on a human body as Jesus Christ and never sinned and thus never had to die. But Jesus came to offer up a sacrifice of Himself to die for the penalty of our sins. As it was foretold 100s of years before Christ appeared. All of us like sheep have gone astray, Each of us has turned to his own way; But the LORD has caused the iniquity of us all To fall on Him. (Isaiah 53:6, NASB*) But He commitmented no sin so was innocent and rose from death to life by the power of God to do this. So Christ lives to give life to those already under the condemnation of sin. It also gives us the Holy Sporit to bear the results of good things like love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, faithfulness, gentleness, self-control; and more. Now that you know these things their is one thing you are still responsible for: the obedience of faith. That is calling on the name of Jesus Christ confessing your sinfulness and seeking forgiveness through Him and then confess Jesus as your savior Lord inviting Him in to your life. As He said. “… therefore be zealous and repent. Behold, I stand at the door and knock; if anyone hears My voice and opens the door, I will come in to him and will dine with him, and he with Me. (Revelation 3:19b,20 NASB*) This is where real hope is found for any soul out their looking for a Savior to rescue them from reaping what they had sowed, and now to Gentiles also who are non Jewish people in the world like I am. that is, the mystery which has been hidden from the past ages and generations, but has now been manifested to His saints, to whom God willed to make known what is the riches of the glory of this mystery among the Gentiles, which is Christ in you, the hope of glory. (Colossians 1:26,27 NASB*) *Permission to Quote the NASB® The text of the New American Standard Bible® may be quoted and/or reprinted up to and inclusive of one thousand (1,000) verses without express written permission of The Lockman Foundation

That’s a tricky question. We must be held accountable for our actions, but I believe you’re asking if the things we do are our “fault” or our “choice”, which is hard to answer. It is becoming more and more understood and accepted every day that much of what we are and what we do is greatly determined by the environment we experience as a child, and further shaped by traumatic events, culture, and circumstances throughout our lives. It’s hard to say where conditioning and influence end and “choice” begins. I’ve heard more than one serial killer describe being triggered by something and then almost entirely blacking out in some sense, only to find they’ve brutally killed someone when they “wake up”. We have to hold them accountable, lock them up for the safety of innocent people, but are they really “responsible”? Furthermore, most serial killers are psychopaths or sociopaths, meaning they literally don’t experience empathy or remorse, and they were either born that way or made that way through immense childhood trauma. Knowing that, can we really say they’re responsible, or that they “made bad choices”, implying that they could have chosen differently? Much of modern psychology would say that it’s unlikely they could have been expected to choose any differently given their condition and circumstances. Conversely, we can’t give anyone too much credit for the good things they do. Most successful CEOs are people born with a certain disposition that makes them productive and decisive (and often a little psychopathic, actually), they were raised in privileged and/or favorable circumstances, and often have uniquely lucky things happen to them along the way. Malcom Gladwell wrote a whole book about it called “Outliers”. TL;DR: Maybe, but not nearly as much as we’d like to think.

As I read your question, I was struck by its simplicity. We all have actions that can be considered improper in time and space. The personal responsibility that we take on is one of the more important foundation stones of Civilization. The three cases where this is applicable are When I do something unthinkingly and do harmWhen I assume that I am doing the right thing and am wrongWhen I willfully do something to harm othersWhen I make a mistake, I am called to make it right as best I can. I may need to make restitution or pay something to the harmed party. Sometimes, an “I’m sorry.” is sufficient. If I do some actions willfully, in an instance of believing that it is the right thing but later am proved wrong, There still need to be a putting of things right. If I harm someone by doing something, even when I thought it was the right thing but it turned out not to be, I need to make amends in the situation. It is just the right thing to do. That third category is a disturbing, but very real, situation. I may be driven by jealousy or a need for revenge. I may only want to take another down a peg or two because I perceive that they are annoyingly proud in some way. The issue is not what they did. It is our response. This is a great evil and we need to be aware of the evil inside us that produces these actions. Most applications of worldview have pathways to deal with the first two but are deficient for the third. The Christian Worldview is the only one that I know that has a way to deal with the personal evil that is inside us all. I highly recommend a thorough investigation of that worldview. Be careful of the counterfeits that are available.

If we first consider that animals are instinctively driven to react to their environment, it becomes easier to understand that we as intelligent human beings, have the free will to make choices, and it is a choice we make to do what is either right or wrong and also good or bad, including that it is a choice we make to lie, and it is therefore obviously a choice we make to make mistakes, and that remains true in spite of the fact that we often don’t know that we are making a mistake. If we choose to deny our responsibility for our own mistakes, the only option left when we discover that there are negative effects as the result of mistakes having been made,, is to blame somebody else and hold them responsible for our mistakes, and that is a choice we make that will have severe negative consequences. Of those negative consequences, it will be a choice we made to absolve our self of our own responsibility that will define who we are as being pitifully weak self-absorbed human beings who are generally not much good to anybody else but our self, and directly because we choose to refuse to accept personal responsibility for our own mistakes, we will naturally be completely oblivious of any of this being true. It also becomes understandable that if we refuse to accept personal responsibility for our own mistakes, we naturally condemn our self to have to repeat the same mistakes, and the reality is that of instead of seeing the world as a wonderful place to explore, we will see the world as a dangerous and threatening place, and that will fuel our fears, and we will naturally be driven to use anger to fight off our fears, and we will naturally be compelled to vent that anger on other people, and that as mean to both, fight off our fears and absolve our self of our own responsibility, and this will have been a choice we made that will very effectively trap us at the mercy of the world. What becomes understandable is that if we do not accept personal responsibility for our own mistakes, it will be a choice we will have made that will be preventing us to be genuinely in charge of our own life, and everything we do that will make us appear as being in charge of our own life will serve to actually confirm that we are living by a lie, and we will learn nothing that really matters from our own life experiences. On the other hand, if we accept personal responsibility for our own mistakes, what becomes understandable is that our mistakes, will also be opportunities to discover what we obviously did not know and most desperately needed to know, which would be at the very least, what would have prevented us from making those mistakes. It therefore becomes understandable that only if we can learn from our own mistakes, that we will have the opportunity to learn from our life experiences and that will have the direct effect of compelling our self to become stronger and wiser people. What also becomes understandable is that personal responsibility is exactly what is absolutely necessary if we are to have legitimate charge of our own life. There may be no greater tragedy, other than a human being refusing to accept personal responsibility for them self and end up living their entire life as an adult child. The inevitable result is that they will not only have ended up wasting their life, but the risk is very high that they might also end up having lived a failed life. Some people believe that a responsible person is someone who can be counted on to arrive on time, always promptly do what is expected from them, like doing their job well and pay their bills on time, etc., but that is not what personal responsibility is about, and all of that can actually be the typical behavior of a human being who is not in legitimate charge of their own life, and it is because they have instead learn only to conform out of their own fears. To have genuine charge of our own life, we must be capable of making the choice of confronting our fears and accepting life as a challenge to risk going into the unknown, and this is exactly what will make life rewarding and interesting, and that is never going to be possible without the acceptance of personal responsibility. It ought to be that by the time they enter into adulthood, every child should fully grasp and understand this to be true, otherwise, they will not have acquire during their formative years, what they needed to make their own way in life. It maybe a truth, that there maybe no greater marker that define a failed life, other than to have failed our own children. It really ought to be that every human being should have somehow manage to learn enough during the span of their life, to be able to claim before they die, “If not for my mistakes, I would have learned nothing that really mattered.

Q: Do you think that we are responsible for our actions? Being responsible for our actions means governing yourself, ownership of your own life, and authority over yourself. Responsibility is ownership and authority. Responsibility is a choice that can only be made voluntarily by the individual. If you fail to make the choice to govern yourself then an external-government will sometimes try to help you or contain you so you do not endanger yourself or others. You lose ownership, authority, and responsibility to the external governing of others. Your parents had to govern you until you did it yourself. Your government has the responsibility to control dangerous criminals because that person doesn't do it themselves. Religion tries to govern those who follow their teachings. But ultimately the individual should take responsibility for everything they are today and govern themselves according to living a happy life while allowing other people to the same. When we blame others what we are actually doing is giving them responsibility over that part of ourselves. We loose ownership and authority and become prisoners and victims to them. But if we take the blame we then own that situation and have authority over it. When you drive a vehicle you are in control. You have taken responsibility and own that situation. You have the authority to create or destroy as you see fit. You have true freedom. The same goes for all your actions. But if you destroy or interfere with others trying to live a happy life also then it is likely that someone will start governing your actions for you. Responsibility is taken. You can try to force others to take responsibility but it never works. They must do it themselves upon their own judgement and free-will. If a person doesn't see a reason to do something they won't do it. Understanding creates hope. Confusion creates fear. Each can be a motivation to act. But only hope gives a lasting good result to empower the individual to govern themselves correctly.

Taking responsibility for your actions is essential if you wish to be a real person in the World. It means that you will never do anything that you can’t bear the responsibility of. Over the past 50 years the people of the richer countries have starved 2 billion children to death in Africa. They have inflicted gargantuan pain on hundreds of trillions of animals. Yet , they all categorically deny that they have anything to do with these atrocious acts. So, that means that nobody has done all this at all, according to them. So, there are billions of people who are in fact responsible for all the evil acts in the World and they are all non-persons. They are so weak that they can’t admit to having responsibility for their actions. They are the pathetic and cowardly bullies of the Universe. It is always the weakest who are the worst. It is the weakest people who do the Devil’s acts for him. A real dignified person instead, is always responsible for all his actions. A group of human beings is always responsible for its actions as a group. In fact, the law of Nature attributes full responsibility to each individual in a group for all actions committed by the group as a whole. This is in contrast to the criminal attitude in which those people who commit the crimes deny all responsibility and point their fingers always at somebody else. And, unfortunately for the weak people who do the Devil’s acts, death itself is avery difficult matter. Death is the most difficult moment of all in life. You have to be very strong and amazingly fast with your reflexes in order to escape from infinite suffering, especially when deep down your conscience is not clean. You can only die safely if you can accept full responsibility for all the actions committed by the people who you are associated with. You are always guilty by association in this world.

let me ask you, A question first who wrote this question on Quora? You or some alien ? you wrote it ,Right ! Only we are responsible for our action and the consequences they yield.Blaming other for it makes no sense. How? Let me tell you a story which i read in a news paper few days back :- A gardener was working in his garden when a cow wandered in and started grazing on a mango sapling. The sight of his favourite sapling being devoured by the cow outraged the gardener so much that he thrashed the animal to death. The news spread like wildfire. Since killing the sacred animal was a sin, the villagers threatened the gardener to face the consequences. But he denied the charge, saying, “No, I didn’t kill the cow — my hand did. And as Lord Indra is the deity of hands, it is the Lord who has incurred the sin, not I.” Indra, who was watching all this from the heaven, disguised himself as an old man and appeared at the scene. He started praising the garden loudly, “What a beautiful garden! Whoever has planted the trees has done it very skilfully and artistically.” The gardener at once turned towards Indra and said, “Thank you, sir. It is my garden. I have planted all these trees with my own hands.” Then the Lord said with folded hands, “When you take credit for all the work done in this garden, it is not proper to hold poor Indra responsible for killing the cow.” Just like the gardener in the story, we are quick to accept any praise or admiration that comes our way; while we cite “God’s will” when anything wrong or tragedy strikes. We must realise that no one else but we are responsible for our actions and the consequences they yield.Blaming other makes, No sense. Thanks for A2A

Only you’re responsible for your actions. Because others may guide, direct, suggest the path to walk. But, they can’t walk on your behalf. You need to walk. So, if you choose to act on a suggestion, it is your choice. If things go wrong, then you can’t blame others for it. You’ll be responsible. Say, on Quora everyday many incredible writers write answers for the questions seeking advice or suggestions. And, you’ll find that at the end of the answer, they write, “You may try.” So, they not guaranteed the success by taking specific action. They suggested that you may. Chances are high. And, for few users it works. But, for some, it don’t. I remember I wrote an answer on Study Habits. And, I got two message from two users. One appreciated and said that the suggested strategy worked for him to clear the exams. While the other told me it didn’t work for him. You can’t blame others for your failures. You chose to take the action. Like, on the packet of cigarettes, it is labeled that “Smoking is injurious to health.”On the medicines, you’ll find a label “Best in use for XYZ months.”On electronic appliances boxes or manuals, you’ll find instructions of DOs & DONTs.So, everyone making a suggestion but the choice will be yours. Therefore, it is your responsibility for the actions you make. Not others.

Nothing in this world can force us to do anything, not even our mood or the circumstances. We have been provided with a brain and a conscience to think before we act. We know what we are doing and why we are doing. We know exactly what the consequence can be...We take a certain step when we think its appropriate. We all have the power to stop it or continue with it..In our life we are provided with various situations and choices. There may be numerous ways to get out of it. The choice we choose directs the future course of the situation and shapes it.One takes a certain decision. This decision can either turn out to be good or bad. Either way the responsibility goes to the person who took the decision. If the decision is good, the person is praised.. if its not the person is blamed.!Absolutely noone analyses the circumstances under which thee person took the decison. It is just "the decision" which is visible to the whole world.We have the power to shape the future.We, and we solely are responsible for our actions....!!!!

You own up to them to yourself. I have at times done good things that I did not take credit for. But if I make mistakes then that is on me and I own up to them to other people as well as to myself. None of us is perfect and we can always make mistakes. But if we do something that we know is wrong deliberately then the consequences should be on ourselves. Sometimes we do things that seemed like a good idea at the time and we should own up to those as well, Often others will forgive and or understand why we made a mistakes. They may have made similar mistakes themselves. But if I did it, the responsibility is mine not someone else’s. What can be more annoying is if someone else takes responsibility for something good that you did or takes credit for things that you accomplished but there is no way to prove that it was your idea or you who did it. And I am willing to bet that a lot of you have experienced that…..Right???

Mexico City, where I was born and raised, has horrible, crippling, paralyzing traffic. It’s impossible to get anywhere on time. The traffic and what it does to your plans and your schedule is very very real - it’s a calamity. But, it has also become the perfect excuse for a generalized lack of punctuality. Everyone is late to everything. People leave a place at the same time they are supposed to arrive at another. They have something to blame. Not to make any less of traffic but it has created a generalized void of accountability. A real problem has become a built-in excuse everyone easily leans on to never bother to be on time. If I am supposed to have dinner with a friend I can call and say “I am giving myself an hour of extra time, but also I will keep you posted along the way.” Or “traffic is likely to be terrible on a Friday afternoon so can we meet on another day?” It’s always possible to adjust. To resist the temptation to resort to easy excuses. To find a way to be the person to follow through on what you say you’re going to do. That’s how you can be accountable for your actions.

Accept your body for what it is. I'm not talking about body image here, but rather emotions. They are crucial aspects of the decision making process. They affect our motivation, decisions, attitude, and even just behavior at large. Emotions can serve as data to help piece together an effective way to navigate an environment. And they all come from within. Our whole lives, we've been developing along a certain path that began when we were young. Our feelings can sometimes go down a path of least resistance, because it's what we're used to. For me, sometimes I face paranoia because it's more natural for my brain to process something through that lense than it is to try and appreciate the whole picture. All emotions come from within. The anger I feel, the paranoia, the fear, the happiness, it all comes from my own body processing the world around me in a way that makes sense to it. Understanding this has helped me reign in my behavior. I know people who will jump to anger and accusations as soon as they become suspicious or paranoid, because it's such an easy way to deal with it; project it outwards, make it someone else's problem, and then they don't have to take ownership of it. It's a conscious choice to slow myself down, to sit with those feelings as unpleasant and terrifying as they are, and truly decide how I want to behave in that situation. Does my girlfriend make me paranoid? No, she doesn't. Sometimes she does things that, because of how I grew up, set off flags in my head that send me into self-preservation mode. It's not intentional on her end. It's how my body responds. I don't want her thinking she's the cause of my paranoia; those feelings come from within, and it's my job to understand that so that I can move forward in a productive manner.

In the eye’s of society and the law … yes, of course … we hold people responsible In reality and fact, based on the best evidence of modern neuroscience … no, not at all … humans simply do not have free-will … you are not the conscious author of your priorities and decisions. Regarding causality, science has only discovered two fundamental mechanisms: deterministic and random So what makes anyone thinks we can suddenly, with respect to human behavior, postulate some ghost in the machine. Some “decider” who is not constrained by past learnings and unconscious priorities. It’s just silly and people who argue otherwise are victims of motivated cognition.

The opposite of responsibility is “irresponsibility”. According to the dictionary, to be responsible is to a : able to answer for one's conduct and obligations : trustworthy b : able to choose for oneself between right and wrong[1] Let’s look at this. Being responsible means you can be trusted by your friends, parents and the people around you. You are also able to choose for yourself between right and wrong. This means you are gaining ‘wisdom’, so an important by-product of being responsible is trust and growth. Can I ask you something? Do you want to be known as ‘trustworthy’? Do you want to be given more ‘responsibility’ for your own decisions, instead of relying on your parents or someone else? Do you want to get a promotion, or want to be encouraged by everyone who saw you being ‘responsible’ with what you were asked to do, or were given? It’s a positive thing to be trusted, isn’t it? Not to have anyone looking over your shoulder, not being nagged at to do the right thing, nor being left out by your friends because they can’t trust you and you failed them in some way. Failure to be responsible leads to people excluding you, or treating you with less respect than you deserve. Think about it. Footnotes[1] Definition of RESPONSIBLE

This question can be looked at from different angles: legal, scientific, ethical, spiritual. And there is a related question about what responsible means, for it suggests that we owe an account or explanation to someone, and its meaning shifts according to how we understand who that someone is—our neighbors? the government? God? All spiritual traditions teach that we are responsible for our actions, which means that we are accountable for them and will face consequences for them. In Buddhism and other traditions that come from India, we’re taught that we are all governed by the law of karma, which unfailingly brings consequences to us for every intentional action we do. Theistic religions have the idea of a final judgment in which the fate of our soul depends on what we have done in life. The teaching is always that pleasant consequences come from good, ethical actions and unpleasant consequences from bad, unethical actions. In this way each one of us is responsible for our actions. Many people profess a materialist outlook that denies freedom and responsibility, but personally I don’t regard that as a tenable position. If there is no such thing as freedom, then the phenomena of consciousness and intelligence have no purpose and no use; their existence is mighty hard to explain. No, we’re responsible. And recognizing this and acting on it, which means acting prudently and ethically, is a hallmark of maturity.

We are partially responsible for ourselves, but not fully. Our thoughts influence our actions but do not control our destiny.Try and will yourself into a fish and see how far you get. We have limitations outside our control as to what we can influence. We have limitations in what we understand and perceive in the world around us. Not everything we call ourself is always in agreement and our thoughts do not have unlimited control ( try thinking yourself into a fish ). Can the audio feedback loop in our heads be held accountable for everything that happens to us? Absolutely not. Do we still have to live with the consequences? Yes So to what level should we be held responsible? To the ability to which we can understand, and control. Instead of assigning responsibility, sometimes it is more optimal to focus on how we can improve it.

Looking from the outside taking responsibility come in two parts. Personal responsibility. Indirect responsibility. Accepting personal responsibility – which is taking ownership of your own behavior and the consequences of that behavior. Until you accept responsibility for your actions or failures, it’ll be very difficult for you to develop self-respect or even have the respect of others. Accepting responsibility is indirect responsibility. It involves moving beyond yourself and taking action to help people or situations around you that call for assistance. The real difference between being responsible and being irresponsible is an indication of how effectively we’re managing our lives when the opportunity to make a good or bad choice presents itself. Accepting responsibility – both personal and indirect responsibility – is one of the most important factors in defining a person’s true character. When that responsible moment comes, what you do – or don’t do – is an indication of the type of person you really are.

You admit you are wrong and no one else to blame. When someone truly takes full responsibility for their actions, they would apologize for the action (if it was wrong) and share within that apology why they believe what they did was wrong. The apology will make it clear whether or not the person is taking full responsibility for something, or if they are just wanting to push the blame to someone else. A classic example of this is something called “left-handed apologies”. A classic example of this is when someone says, “I’m sorry you feel that way” or “I’m sorry you reacted in such a way by what I did to you”. If you actually listen to the words they are using, you will see there is no apology happening at all! The problem is the other person. Nothing wrong happened on his part, the issue was with the other person “feeling bad” or “reacting in a bad way”. If only they didn’t react in a bad way, then there wouldn’t be any issue. The person giving the apology is wanting to “look” like he is truly sorry, but still walk away thinking he/she is on the higher spiritual ground. Pay close attention to what people say. You will learn a lot about a person if you just listen to them. What goes on in their heart, will come out through their mouth.

We are responsible for all of our mistakes, conscious or not. As imperfect humans we stand as sinners before God and deserve His judgement. Yet, God in His great love and mercy has made it possible in Jesus Christ to forgive our sins through faith in His vicarious payment for them. When the human mind and soul are enlightened by God the Holy Spirit, they are on the same page with God and become His children by faith in Jesus Christ. The Holy Spirit works this faith through the message of sins forgiven trusting in the redemption of Jesus Christ that is heard in the Gospel.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Karina Marmolejos and Bahaa Kabil

response.answer_text: Responsibility has value in your personal life, just like money has value in material matters. The more responsible you are, the more trusted you will seem to others. This does not have to translate to doing things for people all the time. Being able to take care of yourself and those important to you, finishing tasks that you are supposed to finish in a timely manner, and just overall being trusted are all factors in being responsible. Sometimes it’s easier to build trust than money, but trust has very much the same value. If you can build trust and network, then you can give yourself more opportunities. This is very scenario based, but being responsible can have its own selfish reasons behind it. Therefore be responsible. You very likely don’t want to live a life where people are doubting your capabilities in anything you do.

We are all members of the human community. Our community can be large or small. Inherent in man’s nature is the desire to communicate and interact with another individual. In the process, man evolves as a social person (or unsocial). This process of becoming a social or unsocial person is a function of a person’s behavior and goodwill unto the other person and vice versa. [* Behavior is a function of our temper and emotional disposition]We make choices, and we make decisions which have consequences and ramifications. And each person has a responsibility to create and maintain a level of decorum and civility acceptable to both parties.If our actions are deemed acceptable to the other person, we can conclude that we’ve both become social and civil persons.The conclusion is each one of us, in our own community, has a responsibility to act with civility and good decorum unto the other. I’m willing to concede that each of us can choose to conduct himself in a hostile manner which can result into an unpleasant event. In whichever case, our individual responsibility for our action(s) stays. *Behavior is a function of one’s personality, and there are four (4): 1) Phlegmatic~Abraham 2) Melancholic~Moses 3) Sanguine~Peter 4) Choleric~Paul

I believe that any and every person that claims conscious awareness is responsible for their own actions including the consequences of those actions. If a person is consciously aware then their sense of identity has been and continues to be developed. The person is able to differentiate good and bad / positive and negative according to their own understandings and contexts. Because of this, their actions become the result of a series of conditions and decisions all of which result in consequences which the person takes responsibility for. Accepting responsibility not only reflects developing maturity but also reflects that the person has a gained both a sense of identity and as such accountability, that is, the person takes responsibility for their actions/behaviours.

Yes for them that have free will absolutely. The person then having done what so ever The Father needed of His election to do the person may or may not even realized they've assisted their Lord. "Ultimately" I can't say- I'm all-too-human and so not from those regions. But.....I do believe that it is possible to find a form of determinism behind each and all of our actions: this ideology, that set of economic conditions/ gender assumptions, etc, etc. I also hold that if we give up the search to do so we abandon all our attempts at understanding, empathy, compassion... In other words, all our efforts to achieve a fuller humanity. Yet...I also KNOW that if I were to shift the entire weight of responsibility for my actions onto these influences, doubtless highly formative though they might be, I would be turning what I pride myself in calling my sensitive reasoning into the sort of self-deluding excuse-finding I find all too odiously familiar (the SS Commandant who offered his love of his dog and family as proof of his underlying humanity....and anyway was just obeying impossible orders...etc.etc.)So..Someone has to take responsibility for my actions, and maybe, more damningly, failures to act, and it might as well be me. Before death stamps its absurdly reductionist definition upon me I'm still, with ridiculous naiveté , trying to discover and define what it is to be human.

I'm not sure why the word “morally” is in there, but yes, we should generally be accountable for our actions. But, there are interesting exceptions. Should a person with a brain defect be responsible? Should a high-level psychopath like Trump be responsible for the lies, chaos, and destruction, or should the responsibility fall on those who put him into office?

Certainly not. Many people find ways to avoid responsibility, and some (the irresponsible) ignore it entirely. I say this with some authority, because I spent much of my early life both being irresponsible and avoiding responsibility. The interesting part is that while I truly avoided much responsibility, my thinking and my actions corroded my character and my life, so that every day became its own little hell. I don’t recommend it for anyone, but it seems we all have to do our own research into life’s realities. And digging out of that hole was neither quick nor easy.

At the point, do people become responsible for their actions? I have helped some people and gave them good advice and when they keep complaining and not take responsibility for their actions. It is useless especially if one sees a pattern like my narcissist half brother who refuses at 53 to take care of himself which he did before he ran out of money.

Nothing is responsible of anything we all part of the world and we invented the word responsibility to give people the urge to keep working for a better society with no pain or bad feelings we are victims of the current conditions and past consequences if you were born as an animal no one will force you to work or satisfy the society, responsibility is not bad we need it but we can’t blame ourselves or someone for anything, we punish people not because we want the revenge but to prevent bad actions from increasing.

While a person's behavior is either moderated or exacerbated by biological/societal/cultural/group/authority figure compliance (see Zimbardo's and Milgram's empirical results), and society is responsible for education of children for the most part in preparing them to be productive citizens, it is only reasonably responsible for deterrence, detection, prosecution, and control of deviants. Such control measures (e.g., fines, community supervision, incarceration, capital punishment) are dependent on intent and degree of damage.As Eagleman stated, "explanation does not equal exculpation. Societies will always need to get bad people off the streets. We will not abandon punishment, but we will refine the way we punish" (p. 171).“Incognito: The Secret Lives of the Brain,” by Dr David Eagleman, who directs the Laboratory for Perception and Action and the Initiative on Neuroscience and Law, Baylor College of Medicine.

absolutely. every individual are responsible for their own actions. that is why when you did something wrong to somebody you feel guilty about it. then you ask for an apology, right? but some people are just too jerk that they will put the blame to someone else. they are aware that they are responsible for their wrongdoings, yet too arrogant and egoistic to admit.

You need to be accountable for your actions, no matter what. People are far more likely to remember how you dealt with a problem than they are to recall how you created it in the first place. By holding yourself accountable, even when making excuses is an option, you show that you care about results more than your image or ego.

Of course you are responsible for every thing you do while in your physical life. You actually participate in creating what happens, good and bad. You always have choices in each and every event and action. Why would anyone think that they are not responsible for the events that they participate in? Only the unobservant people tend to blame others for their lives. You and I and everyone else create our lives with the good and bad events. The more we recognize this the more we move toward creating joyful, fulfilling lives.

We are held responsible for "our" actions because the action itself would not have occurred if it had not been for your being. Whether you, yourself, have willingly chosen it, is something else entirely. Some might argue that the sum of our experiences and genes have put us in this exact moment, and that our choices are merely a product of the past and genes. Others argue that the past has given us certain experiences that might render us more likely to do something, rather than something else. In other words, probability does not equal neccesity. These debates have not been solved, but still intrigue us to this day.

Unless you have been deemed mentally ill, yes humans are responsible for their actions. God gave each person free will to choose. Hoping we would choose the right way, his way. Yes. Unless you have a diagnosed condition with scientific data verifying you have a neurological disability. Otherwise, yes. Even if your momma, brother or the devil made you do it. It is your choice to accept or refuse. You cannot blame others actions for your choice. But we can learn from our mistakes and change who we are. Others are responsible for their actions and cannot blame you for their choices and actions. Each is solely responsible for their actions and choices.

The things that make you become accountable for your actions are shame, fear of failure, hunger, punishment for crimes against another, etc. Simply allow some hunger for those who don’t work, but don’t let them starve. Allow some shame for those who make poor decisions, so they will be motivated to make better ones, and allow some appropriate punishment for those who commit crimes against another. Allowing some hunger for someone who are poor sure worked on me, in the early days before social welfare was available. When I didn’t work I ate less, or not at all. Therefore, I had a job of one sort or another from a very early age. I didn’t feel neglected or “picke on”. I felt empowered. These days I keep hearing that “food anxiety” is a bad thing. It wasn’t in my case. It was the motivator that eventually led me to most of the successes in my life.

Does a fat baby like cake? Of course. Who else in reality truly decides what you do, but you yourself? Even if a gun is held to your head, you still decide to resist or comply. Simply put, yes. Choice theory supports all humans control only their hopes, dreams, thoughts, and actions. If this premise is true, then any choice, even making no choice, is an agent of direct responsibility. Even when faced with extreme duress, even death, one still has the choice of acting or not. Yes, it may mean making the supreme sacrifice, but it is still a choice. Can someone be held accountable if forced to commit an act that forces one to make a choice against their will? Yes, but this creates an ethical conundrum for anything occurring after, and can be debated forever, but it remains there was still a choice to refuse and suffer. Tough choice, yes, but still a choice. Not so easy, this play on morality and ethics, is it?

Yes, we are definitely responsible for our actions - -nobody else. All our actions have consequences, because we reap as we sow. Or: what we do to others, we eventually do to ourselves. Who is responsible for asking this question here on Quora? Are you suggesting you are not? If you feel like you're not responsible for your own actions, why don't you try to be honest and tell us who you think is? To take responsibility for your actions is to free yourself of the whim or credit of othersーto know that you were in a situation due to the confluence of events you either chose, did not avoid or did not refuse; to know that even if others were involved, your performance is not their responsibility. Finally, when you realize you have little or no free will where reactions are concerned, you begin to change your habits and lifestyle so that you can’t be in situations that will predicate your poor reactions.
